questions.question: After the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, Section 1031 like-kind exchanges are limited to:

options.B: Real property only
options.C: Personal property only
options.D: Inventory and stock

questions.explanation: The TCJA (effective 2018) limited Section 1031 like-kind exchanges to real property only. Exchanges of personal property (equipment, vehicles, art) no longer qualify for nonrecognition treatment. Real property includes land, buildings, and certain improvements.
questions.tip: Post-TCJA: 1031 = real property ONLY. No more personal property exchanges.

questions.question: To qualify for long-term capital gain treatment, a capital asset must be held for:

options.B: At least 12 months
options.C: More than 12 months
options.D: At least 18 months

questions.explanation: Long-term capital gain treatment requires holding the asset for MORE than one year (more than 12 months). Selling on the one-year anniversary results in short-term treatment. The day after the one-year mark qualifies for preferential long-term rates.
questions.tip: LTCG = MORE than 12 months. Day 366 qualifies, day 365 doesn't.

questions.question: Under Section 121, the maximum exclusion on the sale of a principal residence for a married couple filing jointly is:
questions.explanation: Married taxpayers filing jointly can exclude up to $500,000 of gain on the sale of a principal residence ($250,000 for single filers). Both spouses must meet the use test (2 of last 5 years), and at least one must meet the ownership test. Neither spouse can have used the exclusion within 2 years.
questions.tip: Home sale exclusion: $250K single, $500K MFJ. Must meet 2-of-5-year ownership and use tests.

questions.question: The primary tax benefit of using the installment method is:

options.A: Converting ordinary income to capital gain
options.B: Eliminating gain recognition entirely
options.C: Deferring gain recognition until payments are received
options.D: Reducing the basis of the property sold

questions.explanation: The installment method allows sellers to defer gain recognition by reporting gain proportionally as payments are received over time. This spreads the tax liability, potentially keeping the seller in lower tax brackets and providing time value of money benefits.
questions.tip: Installment sale = defer gain to match when cash received. Exception: depreciation recapture recognized in year 1.

questions.question: Property inherited from a decedent generally receives:

options.B: Stepped-up (or stepped-down) basis to fair market value at death
options.C: Zero basis
options.D: The basis the heir paid for any estate taxes

questions.explanation: Property acquired from a decedent receives a stepped-up (or stepped-down) basis to fair market value at the date of death (or alternate valuation date). This eliminates income tax on appreciation during the decedent's lifetime, making inheritance tax-advantageous for appreciated assets.
questions.tip: Inherited property = FMV basis at death. All unrealized gain disappears. Key estate planning benefit.

questions.question: When property with a built-in gain is gifted, the donee's basis is generally:

options.A: Fair market value at the date of gift
options.B: The donor's adjusted basis (carryover basis)
options.C: Zero
options.D: The higher of FMV or donor's basis

questions.explanation: For gifts of appreciated property, the donee takes carryover basis (donor's adjusted basis). This means the built-in gain transfers to the donee. If FMV at gift is less than donor's basis, special dual-basis rules apply for computing gain versus loss.
questions.tip: Gift basis: appreciated property = carryover. Loss property = dual basis (FMV for loss, carryover for gain).

questions.question: In a like-kind exchange, 'boot' received by the taxpayer results in:

options.B: Recognition of gain to the extent of the boot received
options.C: Ordinary income equal to the boot
options.D: Deferral of the boot into future years

questions.explanation: Boot (cash or non-like-kind property received) triggers gain recognition to the extent of the lesser of boot received or realized gain. Boot cannot create or increase a loss. The remaining gain is deferred through reduced basis in the replacement property.
questions.tip: Boot = gain recognized (lesser of boot or realized gain). Boot can't trigger loss recognition.

questions.question: In a deferred Section 1031 exchange, replacement property must be identified within _____ days and acquired within _____ days of the relinquished property transfer:

options.B: 45 days; 180 days
options.C: 60 days; 180 days
options.D: 90 days; 365 days

questions.explanation: Deferred (Starker) exchanges require: (1) identification of replacement property within 45 days of transferring the relinquished property, and (2) receipt of replacement property within 180 days (or the due date of the tax return, if earlier). Both deadlines run from the relinquished property transfer.
questions.tip: 1031 timing: 45 days to identify, 180 days to close. Both start from sale of old property.

questions.question: Section 1245 depreciation recapture applies to gains on the sale of:

options.B: Personal property (equipment, machinery) and certain real property
options.C: Inventory only
options.D: Goodwill and intangibles only

questions.explanation: Section 1245 applies to personal property (equipment, machinery, vehicles) and certain real property like single-purpose agricultural structures. Gain is recaptured as ordinary income to the extent of depreciation taken, not limited to the excess over straight-line like Section 1250.
questions.tip: Section 1245 = personal property recapture. ALL depreciation recaptured as ordinary income (up to gain).

questions.question: Unrecaptured Section 1250 gain on real property is taxed at a maximum rate of:
questions.explanation: Unrecaptured Section 1250 gain (straight-line depreciation on real property sold at a gain) is taxed at a maximum rate of 25%. This is higher than the regular long-term capital gains rates (0%/15%/20%) but lower than ordinary income rates.
questions.tip: Real property depreciation recapture = 25% max rate. Better than ordinary, worse than regular LTCG.

questions.question: Net Section 1231 gains are treated as:

options.B: Long-term capital gains (subject to 5-year lookback)
options.C: Short-term capital gains
options.D: Self-employment income

questions.explanation: Net Section 1231 gains are treated as long-term capital gains (preferential rates), while net Section 1231 losses are fully deductible as ordinary losses. However, the 5-year lookback rule recharacterizes gains as ordinary income to the extent of non-recaptured Section 1231 losses from the prior 5 years.
questions.tip: Section 1231: net gain = LTCG, net loss = ordinary deduction. Lookback rule prevents manipulation.

questions.question: The gross profit ratio in an installment sale equals:

options.A: Gross profit divided by selling price
options.B: Gross profit divided by contract price
options.C: Contract price divided by gross profit
options.D: Selling price divided by adjusted basis

questions.explanation: The gross profit ratio equals gross profit (selling price minus adjusted basis) divided by the contract price. This ratio is applied to each payment received to determine the taxable gain portion. The remainder of each payment is return of basis.
questions.tip: Gross profit ratio = Gross profit / Contract price. Apply to each payment to find taxable gain.

questions.question: Losses on sales between related parties under Section 267 are:

options.B: Disallowed but may reduce the related buyer's subsequent gain
options.C: Disallowed permanently
options.D: Deferred until the property is sold to an unrelated party

questions.explanation: Section 267 disallows losses on sales between related parties. However, when the related buyer later sells to an unrelated party at a gain, the previously disallowed loss can offset that gain (but cannot create or increase a loss). This prevents tax benefit shifting.
questions.tip: Related party loss: disallowed to seller, but buyer can use to offset gain (not create loss).

questions.question: The wash sale rule applies when substantially identical securities are acquired within:

options.B: 30 days before the sale only
options.C: 30 days before or after the sale (61-day window)
options.D: 60 days before or after the sale (121-day window)

questions.explanation: The wash sale rule disallows a loss if substantially identical securities are purchased within 30 days before OR 30 days after the sale date (61-day total window). The disallowed loss is added to the basis of the replacement securities, preserving the loss for future recognition.
questions.tip: Wash sale = 61-day window (30 before + sale day + 30 after). Loss adds to replacement basis.

questions.question: To qualify for the full Section 121 exclusion, the taxpayer must have owned and used the property as a principal residence for at least:

options.A: 1 of the last 3 years before the sale
options.B: 2 of the last 5 years before the sale
options.C: 3 of the last 5 years before the sale
options.D: The entire period of ownership

questions.explanation: Section 121 requires ownership AND use as a principal residence for at least 2 of the 5 years preceding the sale. The 2 years do not need to be consecutive or the most recent 2 years. Partial exclusion may be available for those not meeting the full requirements due to health, employment, or unforeseen circumstances.
questions.tip: Section 121: 2 of last 5 years ownership AND use. Don't have to be consecutive.

questions.question: The basis of replacement property in a like-kind exchange equals:

options.A: Fair market value of replacement property received
options.B: Basis of relinquished property, adjusted for boot and gain recognized
options.C: The contract price paid for the replacement property
options.D: Zero basis

questions.explanation: Replacement property basis equals the basis of the relinquished property, plus any gain recognized, plus any additional cash paid, minus cash received. This substituted basis preserves the deferred gain for recognition when the replacement property is eventually sold.
questions.tip: 1031 replacement basis = old basis + gain recognized + cash paid - cash received. Deferred gain embedded in lower basis.

questions.question: Individual taxpayers may deduct net capital losses against ordinary income up to:

options.B: $3,000 per year
options.C: $5,000 per year
options.D: Unlimited amount

questions.explanation: Individual taxpayers may deduct net capital losses against ordinary income up to $3,000 per year ($1,500 for married filing separately). Excess capital losses carry forward indefinitely and retain their character (short-term or long-term) in the carryforward year.
questions.tip: $3,000 annual capital loss limit against ordinary income. Unlimited carryforward, keeps ST/LT character.

questions.question: Investing capital gains in a Qualified Opportunity Zone Fund provides:

options.A: Immediate exclusion of the invested gain
options.B: Deferral of invested gain and potential exclusion of appreciation after 10 years
options.C: Conversion of ordinary income to capital gain
options.D: 100% exclusion of all gains after 5 years

questions.explanation: QOZ investment provides: (1) deferral of the invested capital gain until December 31, 2026 or earlier disposition, and (2) exclusion of appreciation in the QOZ investment if held at least 10 years. The original basis step-up benefits (for 5 and 7 year holds) expired after 2021.
questions.tip: QOZ: defer gain until 2026, exclude appreciation after 10-year hold. Step-up benefits expired.

questions.question: The $25,000 special allowance for rental real estate losses requires:

options.A: Material participation in the rental activity
options.B: Active participation and AGI below $150,000
options.C: Status as a real estate professional
options.D: The rental property to be commercial real estate

questions.explanation: The $25,000 rental loss allowance requires active participation (a lower standard than material participation) and phases out between $100,000 and $150,000 AGI. Active participation means meaningful involvement in management decisions like approving tenants and setting rent.
questions.tip: $25K rental loss allowance: active participation + AGI under $150K. Phase-out starts at $100K AGI.

questions.question: Section 1244 stock allows individual shareholders to treat losses as:

options.B: Ordinary losses up to $100,000 for married filing jointly
options.C: Long-term capital losses without limitation
options.D: Suspended losses until future capital gains

questions.explanation: Section 1244 allows shareholders to treat losses on qualified small business stock as ordinary losses (rather than capital losses) up to $100,000 per year for married filing jointly ($50,000 for others). This provides immediate tax benefit instead of being limited to $3,000 annual capital loss deduction.
questions.tip: Section 1244: ordinary loss treatment up to $100K MFJ, $50K others. Must be original issue stock.

questions.question: Under Section 1033, gain from an involuntary conversion is deferred if:

options.A: The taxpayer reinvests the proceeds in any property
options.B: The taxpayer reinvests in similar-use property within the replacement period
options.C: The insurance proceeds equal the property's basis
options.D: The conversion results from a personal casualty

questions.explanation: Section 1033 allows deferral of gain from involuntary conversions (casualty, theft, condemnation) if the taxpayer reinvests the proceeds in property similar or related in service or use within the replacement period (generally 2 years, 3 years for condemned real property).
questions.tip: 1033: reinvest in similar-use property within 2 years (3 for condemned real property) to defer gain.

questions.question: In a deferred like-kind exchange, a qualified intermediary (QI) is required because:

options.A: The IRS must approve all exchanges
options.B: The taxpayer cannot have actual or constructive receipt of funds
options.C: The QI provides tax advice on the exchange
options.D: The QI guarantees the value of replacement property

questions.explanation: A qualified intermediary holds the exchange proceeds to prevent the taxpayer from having actual or constructive receipt of funds, which would trigger immediate gain recognition. The QI facilitates the exchange by acquiring the relinquished property, holding proceeds, and acquiring replacement property for the taxpayer.
questions.tip: QI prevents constructive receipt. Funds must go directly to QI, not taxpayer, for valid deferred exchange.

questions.question: If a taxpayer completes a like-kind exchange with a related party, and the related party sells the property within 2 years:

options.B: The deferred gain is recognized by the original taxpayer
options.C: The related party pays the tax on deferred gain
options.D: Both parties may exclude the gain

questions.explanation: If property received in a like-kind exchange with a related party is disposed of within 2 years, the deferred gain is triggered. This prevents basis-shifting transactions among related parties designed to achieve tax-free extraction of appreciated property.
questions.tip: Related party 1031: 2-year disposition by either party triggers deferred gain. Anti-abuse rule.

questions.question: If property is sold on the installment method to a related party who resells within 2 years:

options.A: The installment method continues to apply
options.B: The original seller must recognize remaining gain when the related party receives payment
options.C: The related party recognizes the original seller's deferred gain
options.D: Both parties must file amended returns

questions.explanation: If a related party purchaser resells within 2 years, the original seller must recognize the remaining deferred gain when the related party receives payment from the resale (or the amount of the remaining installment payments, if less). This prevents using related parties to accelerate cash while deferring gain.
questions.tip: Installment sale to related party + resale within 2 years = acceleration of remaining gain to original seller.

questions.question: Section 1202 qualified small business stock (QSBS) exclusion requires the stock to be held for at least:

options.B: 3 years
options.C: 5 years
options.D: 7 years

questions.explanation: Section 1202 requires the QSBS to be held for more than 5 years to qualify for the exclusion (100% for stock acquired after September 27, 2010). The exclusion is limited to the greater of $10 million or 10 times the adjusted basis of QSBS in that corporation.
questions.tip: QSBS exclusion: 5+ year hold, $10M or 10x basis cap. Must be original issue C corp stock, qualified business.

questions.question: Section 1045 allows taxpayers to rollover gain from QSBS held more than 6 months into replacement QSBS if acquired within:

options.B: 60 days
options.C: 180 days
options.D: 1 year

questions.explanation: Section 1045 allows deferral of gain on QSBS held more than 6 months if the proceeds are reinvested in replacement QSBS within 60 days. The deferred gain reduces the basis of the replacement stock. This allows entrepreneurs to diversify without immediate tax.
questions.tip: Section 1045 rollover: 6+ months held, reinvest in new QSBS within 60 days. Combine with 1202 on new stock.

questions.question: In a reverse like-kind exchange (acquiring replacement property before selling relinquished property):

options.A: The transaction automatically fails to qualify
options.B: An exchange accommodation titleholder must hold title to one property
options.C: Both properties must be transferred simultaneously
options.D: The taxpayer may hold both properties indefinitely

questions.explanation: Reverse exchanges use an exchange accommodation titleholder (EAT) to hold title to either the replacement or relinquished property during the exchange period. Rev. Proc. 2000-37 provides safe harbor requirements: the taxpayer cannot own both properties simultaneously for more than the exchange period (180 days).
questions.tip: Reverse 1031: use EAT to hold one property. Can't own both simultaneously. 45-day ID, 180-day completion still apply.

questions.question: Capital gains subject to the 3.8% Net Investment Income Tax include:

options.A: Gains from the sale of an active trade or business
options.B: Gains from the sale of investment real estate
options.C: Gains from Section 1202 QSBS (the non-excluded portion)
options.D: Both B and C

questions.explanation: NIIT applies to investment income including capital gains from investment assets. Gains from passive activities and investment real estate are subject to NIIT. The non-excluded portion of QSBS gains is also subject. Gains from active businesses (not passive) are generally exempt if the taxpayer materially participates.
questions.tip: NIIT on capital gains: applies to investment/passive gains. Active business gains may be exempt.

questions.question: Contributing appreciated property to a charitable remainder trust before sale allows:

options.B: Deferral of capital gains tax through the trust's tax-exempt status
options.C: Conversion of capital gain to ordinary income
options.D: Complete avoidance of all taxes

questions.explanation: A CRT is tax-exempt, so it can sell appreciated property without immediate capital gains tax. The trust distributes income to beneficiaries over time, and gain is recognized as distributed (using ordering rules). The donor receives a charitable deduction for the present value of the remainder interest going to charity.
questions.tip: CRT planning: contribute appreciated property, trust sells tax-free, gain recognized as distributed. Partial charitable deduction.

questions.question: If an installment sale note does not provide adequate stated interest, the IRS will:

options.B: Impute interest at the applicable federal rate, recharacterizing principal as interest
options.C: Treat the entire gain as ordinary income
options.D: Disallow any interest deduction to the buyer

questions.explanation: If stated interest is below the applicable federal rate (AFR), the IRS imputes interest under Section 1274 or 483. This recharacterizes part of the stated principal payments as interest, increasing the seller's ordinary interest income and reducing capital gain. Original issue discount rules may also apply.
questions.tip: Below-market installment notes: IRS imputes interest at AFR. Increases ordinary income, reduces capital gain.

questions.question: A cost segregation study benefits real property owners by:

options.B: Reclassifying building components to shorter recovery periods
options.C: Converting real property to personal property for 1031 purposes
options.D: Eliminating depreciation recapture on sale

questions.explanation: Cost segregation reclassifies building components (electrical, plumbing fixtures, carpeting) from 39-year (commercial) or 27.5-year (residential) property to 5, 7, or 15-year property. This accelerates depreciation deductions, though it increases depreciation recapture on sale.
questions.tip: Cost segregation = accelerated depreciation via shorter-life classification. Increases recapture but provides time value.

questions.question: Under the nonqualified use rules, gain attributable to periods when a principal residence was used for rental or other nonqualifying purposes:

options.B: May not be excluded and is taxable
options.C: Is treated as Section 1231 gain
options.D: Is deferred until a subsequent home sale

questions.explanation: For homes with nonqualified use periods after January 1, 2009, gain allocable to those periods cannot be excluded under Section 121. The exclusion is reduced proportionally based on nonqualified use periods divided by total ownership. Exceptions exist for certain temporary absences.
questions.tip: Nonqualified use (post-2009 rental periods) reduces Section 121 exclusion proportionally.

questions.question: Delaware Statutory Trusts (DSTs) are popular 1031 replacement properties because they:

options.B: Are treated as direct real property ownership for tax purposes
options.C: Have no minimum investment requirements
options.D: Are publicly traded securities

questions.explanation: DSTs are structured so investors are treated as owning an undivided fractional interest in real property, qualifying for 1031 exchanges. Rev. Rul. 2004-86 provides the framework. DSTs allow smaller investors to access institutional-quality properties while deferring gain through 1031 exchanges.
questions.tip: DST = 1031-eligible fractional real estate interest. Passive investment, treated as direct property ownership.

questions.question: When a partner purchases a partnership interest at a premium and the partnership has no Section 754 election:

options.A: The new partner receives stepped-up basis in partnership assets
options.B: The new partner will be taxed on their share of built-in gain when assets are sold
options.C: The selling partner recognizes no gain
options.D: The partnership automatically terminates

questions.explanation: Without a 754 election, the new partner's outside basis does not adjust the inside basis of partnership assets. When appreciated assets are sold, the new partner is allocated their share of gain, effectively being taxed on appreciation they already paid for. Section 754 election prevents this double taxation.
questions.tip: No 754 election = new partner taxed on gain already paid for in purchase price. Always consider 754 election.

questions.question: For Section 1231 purposes, casualty gains and losses on business property are first netted separately before being included in the main Section 1231 computation. If casualty losses exceed gains:

options.A: The net loss enters the main Section 1231 hotchpot
options.B: The net loss is treated as ordinary loss and does not enter Section 1231 computation
options.C: The net loss is carried forward as a capital loss
options.D: The net loss offsets ordinary income dollar for dollar

questions.explanation: Section 1231(a) requires casualty gains and losses on business property to be netted first. If casualties net to a loss, the loss is fully deductible as ordinary loss and does not enter the main Section 1231 computation. If casualties net to a gain, the gain enters the Section 1231 hotchpot.
questions.tip: Section 1231 casualty netting: net casualty loss = ordinary loss (bypasses 1231). Net gain â†’ enters 1231 hotchpot.
